facts.text: Plaintiffs are proprietors of the land in suit in C. S. Khatian No. 611 and Sub-Khatian Nos. 612 and 613 of village Sripur in Touzi No. 2597 of the Burdwan Collectorate.

anchor.surface_text: The plaintiffs are the proprietors of the land in suit in C. S. Khatian No. 611 and Sub- Khatians Nos. 612 and 613 of village Sripur in Touzi No. 2597 of the Burdwan Collectorate.

facts.text: Maharaja of Burdwan is proprietor of lands in village Sripur appertaining to Touzi No. 12 of Burdwan Collectorate.

anchor.surface_text: The Maharaja of Burdwan is the proprietor of the lands in village Sripur appertaining to Touzi No. 12 of Burdwan Collectorate. He let out those lands to the Pals and Goswamis

facts.text: Maharaja let out lands to Pals and Goswamis of Sripur in Putni right.

anchor.surface_text: He let out those lands to the Pals and Goswamis of Sripur in Putni right. The Putnidars also took companyl mining lease of those lands from the Maharaja and, thereafter,

facts.text: Putnidars took colliery mining lease from Maharaja.

anchor.surface_text: The Putnidars also took companyl mining lease of those lands from the Maharaja and, thereafter, both the Maharaja and the Putnidars granted the companyl mining lease of those lands

facts.text: Maharaja and Putnidars granted colliery mining lease to P. K. Chatterji of Ikrah.

anchor.surface_text: both the Maharaja and the Putnidars granted the companyl mining lease of those lands to one P. K. Chatterji of Ikrah who, in his turn, granted a sublease of the same to Messrs.

facts.text: P. K. Chatterji granted sublease to Messrs. Lodna Colliery Co. Ltd., predecessor-in-interest of defendant company.

anchor.surface_text: to one P. K. Chatterji of Ikrah who, in his turn, granted a sublease of the same to Messrs. Lodna Colliery Co. Ltd., the predecessor-in-interest of the defendant companypany, the Lodna Colliery Co.  1920  Ltd.

facts.text: A portion of the lands in suit subsided and plaintiffs found defendant had cut away underground coal from the lands.

anchor.surface_text: A portion of the lands in suit subsided and on enquiry the plaintiffs found that the defendant companypany had cut away a large quantity of the underground companyl from the lands, in suit.

facts.text: Plaintiffs sued defendant for recovery of damages for coal wrongfully taken away and other wrongs based on proprietary right.

anchor.surface_text: It is on account of such unjustified companyduct of the defendant companypany that the plaintiffs, on the basis of their proprietary right, used for the recovery of damages for companyl wrongfully taken away by the defendant from the land in suit and for other wrongs.

facts.text: Defendant contested suit and denied plaintiffs' title to sub-soil and consequently to coal.

anchor.surface_text: The defendant companypany companytested the suit and denied the plaintiffs alleged rights on the ground, inter alia, that the plaintiffs had numbertitle to the sub-soil of the land in suit and companysequently to the companyl.

facts.text: Land in suit permanently settled with plaintiffs after resumption as invalid Lakhraj land.

facts.text: Trial Court held invalid Lakhraj tenure resumed under Regulation II of 1819, permanently settled with plaintiffs at fixed revenue, so plaintiffs had right to minerals; decreed suit in part.

anchor.surface_text: The Trial Court held that the invalid Lakhraj tenure in the land in suit in favour of the predecessors-in-interest of the plaintiffs was resumed by the Government under the provisions of Regulation II of 1819 and, thereafter, was permanently settled with them at the fixed revenue and that therefore the plaintiffs had right to the minerals under the soil of the land settled with them. It accordingly decreed the suit in part

facts.text: High Court confirmed the decree of Trial Court.

anchor.surface_text: and the decree was companyfirmed by the High Court.

facts.text: Robakari of Deputy Collector of Burdwan dated April 15, 1841, for Touzi No. 2597; permanent settlement made with Madhusudan Roy and Sitaram Roy, predecessors of plaintiffs.

anchor.surface_text: Exhibit 10 is the Robakari of the Deputy Collector of Burdwan, dated April 15, 1841, with respect to Touzi No. 2597. It is in pursuance of this order that permanent settlement was made with Madhusudan Roy and Sitaram Roy, predecessors-in- interest of the plaintiffs with respect to the land in suit.

facts.text: Government decree in April 1837 resumed invalid revenue free land (Brahmottar 156 bighas 10 cattahs, Debutter 18 bighas 20 cattahs, total 175 bighas) in village Pariharpur etc.

anchor.surface_text: It appears from this Robakari that in proceedings between the Government as plaintiff and Manik Chandra Roy, Madhusudan Roy, Sitaram Roy and others as defendants, the claim of the Government, in accordance with the provisions of Regulation II of 1819 and Regulation III of 1828, in respect of the invalid revenue free land company sisting of Brahmottar land measuring 156 bighas 10 cattahs and the Debutter land measuring 18 bighas 20 cattahs, in all 175 bighas, situated in village Pariharpur and other villages within Pergana Shergarh, was decreed in April 1837, with the result that that land was resumed and assessed to land revenue.

facts.text: Settlement made with Manik Chandra Roy on April 19, 1838.

anchor.surface_text: The settlement was however made with Manik Chandra Roy on April 19, 1838, as the other defendants did number turn up.

facts.text: Amalnama Exhibit 2 issued by Deputy Collector Burdwan on April 15, 1841 to Mukhyas directing payment of rents to settlers.

anchor.surface_text: On April 15, 1841, Amalnama, Exhibit 2, was issued by the Deputy Collector, Burdwan, to Mukhyas and others. It directed them to pay their respective rents to the persons with whom settlement was made.

facts.text: Supreme Court held plaintiffs have rights to sub-soil minerals as proprietors like zamindars.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the right of property of the person with whom resumed invalid Lakhraj land had been settled, being the same as of the zemindars, extends to the sub-soil minerals of the land held by them.

arguments.court_reasoning: Regulations confirm proprietors have full property rights including sub-soil

arguments.claim: under Regulation XIX of 1793 grantees or possessors of alienated lands are proprietors with same right of property as proprietors of estates subject to revenue

anchor.surface_text: We shall first consider Regulation XIX of 1793. Regulation XIX of 1793 was made for reenacting with modifications the Rules passed by the Governor-General in Council on December 1, 1790, for trying the validity of the titles of persons holding, or claiming a right to hold, lands exempted from the payment of revenue to Government, under grants and for determining the amount of the annual assessment to be imposed on lands so held which might be adjudged or become liable to the payment of public revenue. ... with the same right of property therein as is declared to be vested in proprietors of estates or dependent taluks

arguments.claim: zemindars recognized as actual proprietors of the soil under Regulations VIII, I, II of 1793

anchor.surface_text: Now, Regulation VIII of 1793, also passed on May 1, 1793, re-enacted with modifications and amendments the Rules for the Decennial Settlement ... the property in the soil has been declared to be vested in the landholders, and the revenue payable to Government from each estate has been fixed for ever

arguments.claim: Privy Council in Ranjit Singh v. Kali Dasi Debi recognizes zamindars as proprietors of soil post-1793 settlement

anchor.surface_text: Such a view was expressed by the Privy Council also in Ranjit Singh v. Kali Dasi Debi. It was said at page 122 Passing to the settlement of 1793, it appears to their Lordships to be beyond controversy that whatever doubts be entertained as to whether before the British occupation the zamindars had any proprietary interest in the lands comprised within their respective districts, the settlement itself recognizes and proceeds on the footing that they are the actual proprietors of the land

arguments.claim: zamindars have rights to sub-soil minerals as proprietors; tenure holders do not unless expressly conferred (citing Hari Narayan etc.)

anchor.surface_text: The right of the zemindars to the sub-soil minerals under their land follows from their being proprietors of the soil and has been recognized in a number of cases between the zemindars and persons holding land under a tenure from them. It has been held in those cases that, in the absence of the right to sub-soil minerals being conferred on the tenure holder under the terms of the tenure held by him, he does not get any right to them. The first such case is Hari Narayan Singh v. Sriram Chakravarti.

arguments.claim: settled persons on resumed Lakhraj have same property rights as zemindars extending to sub-soil minerals

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the right of property of the person with whom resumed invalid Lakhraj land had been settled, being the same as of the zemindars, extends to the sub-soil minerals of the land held by them.

arguments.claim: documents (Exhibits 10,2,6a) show permanent settlement after resumption under Reg II 1819/III 1828 conferring proprietary rights under superior interest of Crown like zamindars

anchor.surface_text: Exhibit 10 is the Robakari of the Deputy Collector of Burdwan, dated April 15, 1841, with respect to Touzi No. 2597. ... It describes the interest in the land in suit to be Bajeapti resumed Lakheraj Pariharpur and others. ... They must consequently have the same rights which other proprietors like zamindars had.

arguments.claim: prior records show Brahmottar/Debutter lands so no sub-soil rights absent express conveyance per Hari Narayan principle
arguments.court_reasoning: predecessors held land from Government not subordinate tenure from zamindars so principle does not apply

arguments.claim: plaintiffs rightly held to own minerals under land and decree correct

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the plaintiffs had rightly been held to own and possess the rights the minerals under the land in suit and that the decree in their favour is correct.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the right of property of the person with whom resumed invalid Lakhraj land had been settled, being the same as of the zemindars, extends to the sub-soil minerals of the land held by

holdings.reasoning_summary: Interprets Regulations of 1793 (XIX, VIII, I, II) to vest grantees/possessors of revenue-liable alienated lands with same proprietary rights as zamindars/landholders, who own soil and sub-soil minerals per precedents; applies to post-resumption settlements under Reg II 1819/III 1828

holdings.text: the possessors of the Bajeapti resumed Lakheraj land in suit held it as proprietors under the King Emperor of India. They must consequently have the same rights which other proprietors like zamindars had

anchor.surface_text: It is thus clear that the possessors of the Bajeapti resumed Lakheraj land in suit held it as proprietors under the King Emperor of India. They must consequently have the same rights which other proprietors like

holdings.reasoning_summary: Documents (Exhibits 10, 2, 6a) evidence permanent settlement post-resumption under Reg II 1819/III 1828 directly from Government, conferring proprietary rights equivalent to zamindars

holdings.text: the plaintiffs had rightly been held to own and possess the rights the minerals under the land in suit and that the decree in their favour is correct

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore of opinion that the plaintiffs had rightly been held to own and possess the rights the minerals under the land in suit and that the decree in their favour is correct.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies above principle to facts and documents confirming plaintiffs' proprietary title post-resumption settlement, upholding lower courts' decrees

holdings.text: We do not agree with this contention. The predecessors-in-interest of the plaintiffs held the land from the Government and not on a subordinate tenure from the zamindars and therefore the principle of law as stated in Hari Narayan Singhs Case and later confirmed in several decisions by the Privy Council, does not apply to the present case
holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes Privy Council tenure cases (Hari Narayan etc.) requiring express mineral rights in subordinate grants from zamindars; here direct Government settlement post-resumption confers full proprietary rights

precedents.cited_proposition: tenure holder from zamindar has no right to sub-soil minerals unless conferred by terms of tenure

precedents.citation: Sashi Bhushan Misra v. Jyoti Prashad Singh Deo 3

anchor.surface_text: Sashi Bhushan Misra v. Jyoti Prashad Singh Deo 3

precedents.case_name: Sashi Bhushan Misra v. Jyoti Prashad Singh Deo
precedents.cited_proposition: when a grant is made by a zamindar of a tenure at a fixed rent, minerals will not be held to have formed part of the grant in the absence of express evidence to that effect
precedents.cited_holding: These decisions, therefore, have laid down a principle which applies to and concludes the present dispute. They establish that when a grant is made by a zamindar of a tenure at a fixed rent, although the tenure may be permanent, heritable and transferable, minerals will not be held to have formed part of the grant in the absence of express evidence to that effect.
